H0.text: A collision is the only way asteroids, which are not geologically active, can change.

H1.text: Propulsion is the only way asteroids, which are not geologically active, can change.

H2.text: Combustion is the only way asteroids, which are not geologically active, can change.

H3.text: Expansion is the only way asteroids can change, since asteroids are not geologically active.

A4.text: Active asteroids are objects that have asteroid-like orbits but show comet-like visual characteristics.

A5.text: For asteroids rotating faster than approximately this rate, the inertial force at the surface is greater than the gravitational force, so any loose surface material would be flung out.

A6.text: Impact events appear to have played a significant role in the evolution of the Solar System since its formation.

A7.text: Interplanetary impacts have also been proposed to explain the retrograde rotation of Uranus and Venus.

A8.text: Earth Impact Effects Program Estimates crater size and other effects of a specified body colliding with Earth.

A9.text: Asteroids with a diameter of 20 m (66 ft), and which strike Earth approximately twice every century, produce more powerful airbursts.

A10.text: The 2013 Chelyabinsk meteor was estimated to be about 20 m in diameter with an airburst of around 500 kilotons, an explosion 30 times the Hiroshima bomb impact.
